title: Error regarding Googlequicksearchbox in camera of P9 Lite

thread.text:
Hello,
Happy New Year to you all!
I have owned a Huawei P9 Lite for roughly 6 months now and am quite happy with it. However, for the past few days, I've been having the following problem ...
Whenever I open the camera, I get an error, which, roughly translated from Dutch, says "Camera is recording audio. Com.google.android.googlequicksearchbox:interactor can't open at the moment"
(I added a screenshot)
If I tap "OK", the error message disappears, but pops right up again seconds later. I can use the camera, but it is of course very annoying if you can't see what you're snapping pictures of.
I've been Googling about this and I found out that Quicksearchbox refers to a search box or Google Now. However, I do not have a search box widget on my screen and I also don't see the connection between the camera and that, nor the link with Google Now.
I can't find any topics about the entire error on Google.
Does anyone have any idea what's going on? I would prefer not to do a factory reset if not necessary.
Greetings,
Lenny

replies.text: I have the same problem, so I go to "OK GOOGLE" detection, and switch off the "from any screen". Done.

thread.text: Welcome to Android Central! Try wiping the cache partition: http://www.solvemix.com/index.php/an...rtition-solved. If the problem persists, see if it goes away in Safe Mode: http://consumer.huawei.com/ca/suppor...a.htm?id=55398. If it does, then something you installed is interfering. You might have to uninstall apps one by one until the problem goes away.

replies.text:
Thank you... Clearing the cache seems to have done the trick! 
Lenny

thread.text: Great! Let us know if the problem returns.

Also I am facing same problem with mate 9 .
While using some apps like yeecall,WhatsApp or even phone above error will pop-up.
In the begining I thought it's a software issue and I did reset the phone twice but nothing happened.
So please advice

replies.text: I just bought a P9 yesterday and had the same problem, the issue is that I had enabled "OK Google" to work from every screen, soon as I disabled that, the error stopped showing up in various apps. To bad the mic can't handle two apps at a time :/

thread.text:
Just to confirm what Gretar has said, go to your Google Now settings - Voice - and disable the bit where you can access Google now from any screen by saying "OK Google". I had exactly this problem but as soon as I disabled this it sorted it out. 
Obviously the 'ok google from any screen' setting means having the microphone permanently on, which seemingly causes lots of issues in other apps.

Hey guys i just fixed it like 15 mins ago.
so apparently the problem occurs when u have the google app that can recognize your voice when you say like "OK google"
so i figure i can just disable(deny) Google permission to use microphone. it works but i wont be able to quickly do a quick google search by using my voice, which used to be very helpful to me.
so what i did next instead is to go to the Google App i found on the menu. Settings, > Voice > "OK google" detection and just disable "From any screen". tested it out and it works.
by enabling this you can say ok google anywhere INCLUDING IN CAMERA MODE. but by disabling it you will need to be on the home menu for it to work if im not mistaken.
so yea thats it. hope this helps

I fixed it by opening the camera app on normal photo mode then swiped right to settings and then scrolled down to the bottom and clicked restore defaults. A message then pops up to say 'camera settings will be restored to their default values.' I clicked ok and then swiped back onto camera mode. A couple of messages came up for permissions like allowing location service so I accepted the ones I wanted. I had no message about ok Google though as I don't use it so maybe it's best to decline that if it comes up on yours. I then clicked on the video function, pressed record and it records as normal. Problem fixed! Yay! 
Hope this works for you.

title: Is an email required for Huawei P9 hard reset?

thread.text:
I forgot the unlock password for my Huawei P9 and since I want to do a factory reset anyway I thought I would do a hard reset.
I understand that Huawei P9 requires entering an email address when doing a factory reset. Is an email address also required when doing a hard reset? If it is, when would I enter it and would I be prompted?
My questions may seem silly but I want to know what's required before I start a hard reset.
Thanks, Lance

Welcome to Android Central! If you do a hard reset without first removing the primary Google account, it's considered an unauthorized factory reset. This means that after the reset, you have to enter that previous Google account and password to proceed. This is meant to discourage thieves from stealing a phone and doing a simple factory reset to make it their own.

title: why my micro sd-card get corrupted evry while in Huawei p 9 lite

thread.text: I have Huawei p 9 lite internal memory 16 g so I bought micro sd card of 16 also it work for a while then I can't save any thing on it nor transfer it to computer ,it say error ,corrupted but I can view it content but I can't write on it , this happened twice so I thought something wrong in the device it self that destroy the sd cards repetitively ...can you help me to repair this sd card and how to avoid it in the future ???

If you installed it as adoptable storage (or internal storage), the phone doesn't see the card, it just sees 32GB of internal storage. You can't write to the card and have it used as internal storage.
If you install it as portable storage, you'll be able to write to it, but the phone will have only 15GB of internal storage again. (Meaning that you can save files [pictures, videos, music, etc.] to the card, but you can't install apps on it.)

title: How to transfer my pictures from my Huawei P9 to my PC

thread.text:
Hello everybody, 
Quite new to this. My girlfriend has bought a P9 and has managed to fill in all the internal storage with pictures etc. Connect the phone on the PC and we cannot see any files. How can I access the files in the phone and back them up in my PC. She does not have a micro SD card in the phone would that be the easiest way of transferring the data?
She is not very tech savvy and even though I'm good on dealing with technology I'm not an Android user so if you go slow on me it will be amazing.

Welcome to Android Central! Connect the phone to the PC via USB, swipe down on the notification panel, tap the USB icon, and make sure MTP or File Transfer is selected. Then open Windows Explorer on the PC and open the phone in the device list. You can now drag and drop files from the phone storage to the PC's hard drive. Photos taken by the camera app are in the /DCIM/Camera directory.
I would also strongly recommend taking advantage of Google Photos auto backup: https://support.google.com/photos/an...DAndroid&hl=en

Welcome to Android Central! Don't bother with HiSuite. Instead, connect the phone to your computer via USB, then swipe down the notification panel and tap the USB notification there. Make sure MTP or File Transfer is selected.

title: Transfer notes to Huawai P9

Welcome to Android Central! What app did you use on the HTC phone to make the notes? The problem with the stock note-taking apps on various phones is that they are often not interchangeable (and the app doesn't always have a sync or backup function). That's why I strongly recommend using Google Keep.

That will probably depend on how the notepad app on other phones creates and saves notes, and if the app has any kind of export function. The notepad app will differe depending on the manufacturer, and sometimes the same manufacturer will have a newer notepad app on newer phones, compared to their older phones.

title: Hotmail

thread.text: I would like it if when I delete an email on my phone, it will also be deleted from my actual hotmail account, how can I achieve this please? I am a new hauwei user (used iphone since forever...) thanks

replies.text:
Did you ever get this figured out? Just bought a P9 plus yesterday and got everything, including my outlook/hotmail account setup. I setup an Exchange account. On Huwaei, you do this by going to Account->Add an account->Corporate. Enter Email Address, username, password. Email Address/username will be the same. That *should* work. There are other settings behind that, but they are set correctly (except maybe one).
*If*, Using the standard account setup doesn't work, it may be the server. By default it is m.hotmail.com. On my previous phone that worked. On the phone before that, I used eas.outlook.com. If the standard account setup fails, go to the manual setup and change the server to eas.outlook.com. Port and Security Type is already correct.
Once you do that and it works, you can setup everything you want to sync. I sync everything, contacts, calendar, email, but you may only want email. I set up the account "sync schedule" to push, so I get email as soon as it arrives. Also, when I delete emails, they get deleted on the server (which is what you are wanting). 
Hope that helps.

thread.text: Kind of unrelated, but what Huawei are you using? Do you like it and would you recommend someone else to make the same purchase?
It's a P9 and I really like it, dont miss having an iphone which I thought I would! Just want to sort this email business out... 😊

Hello, from my experience (always used Hotmail and the respective app) the problem is not on the phone but the app itself.It seems to somehow lack that synchronization with the inbox elsewhere. Even on windows phone where it is a native service.

replies.text: Hi, I don't use the app, I just assigned my hotmail account to my phone and when I had it set up like this on my iphone, it worked fine, if I deleted an email on my phone, it would be deleted from my hotmail account, confused... ������

thread.text: Thanks, I'm all sorted now.

Good to hear your sorted.. but email works like this:
Exchange / IMAP / IMAP 4.. are server based - so your logged into your email server... delete it from the phone and it deletes from server..
POP / POP3 is device based... It basically "Downloads" it to your device from server, so deleting mail.. only deletes it from the device..
Hope that helps

title: Mobile data not always working

Hi!
I purchased a brand new P9 32GB two weeks ago and im really happy with it most of the time. If it's universally restricted, then you have to go to that menu and turn off Restrict Background Data. But are you saying that even if you do this, you have to restart the phone to get it to work?

On a iPhone i remember this was flawless. If i had for example Snapchat turned off for mobile data use, i could easily turn on mobile data, then enable mobile data for Snapchat and i would be good to go.

thread.text:
In that Networked Apps>Advanced Network Management menu>Background Data menu, what exactly does the option say? Can you show us a screenshot? http://forums.androidcentral.com/gen...d-central.html

You mean like this?

title: My first 2 days with my P9... A Brief review

thread.text:
So I unboxed my P9 nearly 2 days ago now.. and.. I like it.. alot, so heres just a short trivew so far: 
Who needs a 2k screen on phone, seriously and when using the P9... I really cant tell Im using a 1080p screen.. its so crisp and clear and really bright.. great colour depth and rich reds and blues.... I cant comment on battery yet.. but ill add it at a later date.. 
As Ive only unboxed my P9, the shots ive taken have all been on AUTO, SOO.. the camera is not as DSLR amazing as Huawei claim it is.. but its very good, nice and crisp if a little lifeless and flat on a dull day (Like today).. its on a par with the S6 edge, amd the G4.. but not quite the G5... however, that said.. it has so many settings to tinker and experiment with, its possible to make alot of changes... It doesnt have OIS.. but I dont think it needs it, the EIS or DIS.. does a fantastic job... out of 21 photos.. I only lost 3 to camera shake, and even then.. it was my own fault
Sadly, the P9 only has a 1.25 micro pixel size, compared to the S7E, 6P and G5.. which have a 1.55 micron, which means the P9 cam detail does suffer a little when being heavily cropped in that being said,, I really like the camera as it can deliver some truely stunning shots.. but sometimes a softer image is what looks the best.. not every photo has to be super crispy.. especially in macro or candid photography... So, well done, Huawei.. you made a good one.. keep it up.. Unfortunately, YouTube has everyone going hysterical and slamming Devs if you cant read a car number plate Cropped In 1000x from half a mile away with your latest camera on your phone..
Loud voices in phone calls, Build quality is beautiful.. much nicer and sexier than a Samsung... The single speaker is surprisingly good and quite full sounding..nice and loud for RingTones... its on a par with the G5.. Headphone Audio is eally great using Sennheiser 422s and LG Quadbeat 3s, loud and punchy.. plenty of depth and instrument separation, but can struggle in choral works.. playing Def Leppard, Bee Gees, Mark Knopfler, Vangelis and Franz Lizst "Missa Choralis", and with it having an SDCard.. you can rip in flac...
TBH... Theres not alot wrong with this phone at all.. so far... yes there was too much hype made about the "Amazing" camera.. which is truely great, but wont replace my Canon DSLR quite yet.. but the fantastic audio side, stunning 1080p screen, awesome build quality and, IMO, interesting EMUI 411 make it a pleasure to use.

Enjoy! 
The camera takes a little getting used to to figure and get good results but is worth the effort IMHO.

hi, i want to ask you few questions about the p9, because i want to buy a new phone and i read some bad comments about the max vol on headphones, its true? i mostly play rock- electronic music and what can you say about the signal strenght from the wifi and 4g antenna?.

Music Volume is loud.. You don't need max volume on the P9, but I don't get any signal breakup or distortion when I play Loud.. about 85 - 90%.. I use Sennheiser HD432s for serious listening and LG Quadbeat 3 buds for outdoors and both are really great IMO. no issues..

title: File management on P9

thread.text:
I want to use the internal memory for apps,... (System based stuff) But I want to use the MicroSD card for all data. (Photo's, Music, Podcasts, Documents,...) A bit like a desktop environment.
In settings -> advanced settings -> memory and storage -> standard location: I switched it to the MicroSD card. (Note the menu route is a translation of the settings)
But I'm a bit worried I didn't need to do that because now I have a Android, LOST.DIR,... folder on MicroSD card. Is my system running on the MicroSD now?
What is the correct setting for what I want to do? 
Thanks for the help!

Welcome to Android Central! No, the system won't run off the SD card. Any time you insert an SD card in an Android device, it will create an Android directory (which the system will use to save certain non-crucial bits of data) and a LOST.DIR directory (which is where broken files get stored, in case you have to try recovering them).

Ah so I did need to switch the standard location as I did? 
Will app's still be installed on the P9 or will they be installed on the MicroSD?

When you switch the storage location, that's only for files you download, and possibly for apps to store data (but not to save the actual app files). If you go to Settings>Apps and select an app, then tap Move to SD, that will move part of the app itself to the SD (but not the whole thing). The only way for an entire app to be installed to the SD is if you're on Marshmallow or above, and are able to format an SD card as Internal Storage (i.e., Adoptable Storage).
That's great! System and storage separated. Exactly how it seems right for me.

No--factory reset isn't quite the same as reinstalling the firmware. A factory reset will use the firmware that is currently installed on your phone, and revert it to factory settings--but if the firmware is corrupt, then you won't be fixing the underlying problem. Reinstalling the firmware puts a fresh uncorrupted copy of the firmware on the phone.

I'm not a fan of putting apps onto sd cards myself, you only get some of the app on the card, the guts of it stays on the device anyway. And with your encrypted phone vs unencrypted card you are setting yourself up for grief I reckon. Put your media on the card and leave the apps in device is what I'd do. No doubt you'll get more feedback here from other more knowledgeable peeps than myself tho....
do you have any idea how can i move the app to sd card ? or is it possible on my huawei p9 lite ?

Welcome to Android Central! My guess is that the option you mention will change the default data storage and download location to the SD card instead of internal storage--but this is only for data files, and not for app installation. The ability to move an app to SD depends on the phone (as well as the app itself), so if you go to Settings>Apps, select apps, and don't see a Move to SD button, then it's not possible (either on the phone, or for that app). Moreover, moving an app to SD only moves a portion of the app (and often a relatively small portion), so your internal storage savings my not be that much.

I have a Huawei Watch paired to my Nexus 6P, and in general I love it--primarily because of how it looks. I think this watch most closely resembles a classic men's dress watch, compared to all other Android Wear watches currently available. Since I love changing up how the watch looks, and since I appreciate watchfaces that look like real watches, I highly recommend WatchMaster (which is different from another popular app called WatchMaker).
Another useful feature is using the watch as a remote camera shutter. If you use the Google Camera app, when you open it on the phone, a watch notification should appear that allows you to use it as a camera shutter release. If you don't use the Google Camera app, there are some 3rd party remote camera apps available on Google Play.

I've recently bought a P9 Lite which, I think, software side it should be the same as a P9, so Android 6.0 with EMUI 4.1. Since the storage isnt' that much (16 GB), I've bought a 32 GB Micro SD card but I'm having a hard time understand how the system handles it.
By default, I've noticed that, when I inserted it, the phone has automatically started to save some things on it, like pictures and videos taken with the camera. However, some other things, like apps or offline maps by Google, are still saved on the main memory.
In the phone settings I've found an option to switch, as main memory, from the internal one to the SD Card, but Huawei doesn't clear explain what this option really do. I only get a warning to pay attention to my data since the internal memory is encrypted, while the SD no.
Is there someone that can help me to understand the real meaning of this option?
Thanks!
Best

I'm not a fan of putting apps onto sd cards myself, you only get some of the app on the card, the guts of it stays on the device anyway. And with your encrypted phone vs unencrypted card you are setting yourself up for grief I reckon. Put your media on the card and leave the apps in device is what I'd do. No doubt you'll get more feedback here from other more knowledgeable peeps than myself tho....
do you have any idea how can i move the app to sd card ? or is it possible on my huawei p9 lite ?

Welcome to Android Central! My guess is that the option you mention will change the default data storage and download location to the SD card instead of internal storage--but this is only for data files, and not for app installation. The ability to move an app to SD depends on the phone (as well as the app itself), so if you go to Settings>Apps, select apps, and don't see a Move to SD button, then it's not possible (either on the phone, or for that app). Moreover, moving an app to SD only moves a portion of the app (and often a relatively small portion), so your internal storage savings my not be that much.
Duplicate threads merged.

thread.text:
Yeah.... looking at those gsmarena test stills, I'm not all that impressed. There's a LOT of digital junk, smudged up details... there's a surprising lack of finite detail in every shot, even the B&W image, which doesn't involve any image merging based on their press material. The 1:1 looks are kind of a mess, if you showed me those I would in no way, shape or form say there was any benefit to a dual camera.
Much disappoint.  I mean, the concept should allow for some incredible pictures... razor sharp detail (without the processing artifacts), excellent dynamic range, etc. The approach is used in optical astronomy to great effect, and there are ground based telescopes that use a similar mechanism (along with some other tricks) to lead to images with resolution that's absolutely staggering. I', going to chalk this up to "because first"... and hope that subsequent attempts will lead to better quality.

replies.text:
I just looked at them, and what hit me at first was "Where's all the detail?"
To my eyes, it's apparent that there doesn't seem to be a lot of detail in the P9's camera. Some might say it's due to the 12-megapixel resolution, but I don't really think the 12MP resolution is really to blame here. I zoomed in and there seems to be quite a bit of digital-noise and the noise-reduction is kinda smudgy. Dynamic range is also kinda "Ehhh", but I've seen worse.
As of this time, I don't think there's any benefit to a dual-camera setup like this. It has potential, but for some reason, it isn't fully realized yet. I'm chalking this up to software processing and I hope that Huawei/Leica will improve the way images are processed because this camera has potential and it needs the software to realize it. If it's hardware, well, at least they're the first to do it this way?
(The GSMArena shots I looked at are here. Leo probably used the same set.We have Huawei P9 camera samples, check them out - GSMArena blog)

That 12MP has less detail is a myth actually. If you crop a 16:9 16MP to 4:3, you get a 12MP picture. Any 'loss of detail' will be related to differences in field of view, which isn't really a loss in detail in the first place.
Besides... Both the S7 and 6P are 12mp and the pictures they push out are light years beyond what we saw here.
New tech, needs some seasoning.

That's what I thought too.
I've used a couple of 12MP cameras and I never found any loss of detail compared to my G4. So when I saw how the P9's photos seem to lack any sense of detail despite having that resolution, I'm pretty certain that it has to be something else.
I'm thinking that it's smudgy noise-reduction or maybe the way the phone takes the imaging data from the 2 sensors is a bit iffy right now.
Well, it is decidedly "First-Gen", and that's pretty much what I think.

This maybe only a problem with mine, but I have the P9 and I got a 32Gb SD card and transferred all my photos across onto it. Then the SD card started having problems and the phone said that the SD card was corrupted. I stained my undies a little but when i put the SD card into my computer I managed to retrieve most of the videos and photos. I have decided NOT to continue using an SD card as do not want to risk losing all my files. I guess if storage becomes an issue then I will just backup all the files from the SD card onto my computer every week. At least if it goes corrupt again, then at least I will have the majority of my files safe! 
With regards to your question, I was a little confused too so ended up going to the Files icon in the Tool sub-folder and then just manually copied and pasted them across from phone onto SD card. Haven't found an easier option as yet, but probably because I stopped using the card.

Go to File Manager -> Device Storage or emulated/0 -> DCIM -> Then find the Folder and copy it.
If your Folder is not there, then go to Device Storage or emulated/0 -> Pictures -> Find the folder and copy/move it.

title: Quick charging P9

thread.text:
Anyone using the P9 quick charging brick have done any comparison with regular QC compatible charger?
I noticed charging with the Huawei Quick Charge charger (bought separately) it charges relatively quick till about 85%-90% then it throttles the charge to a crawl. Really.... Slowly. I know it's normal to avoid damaging the battery in the long run. It's ridiculously slow, the last 10% would take another 20-25mins to complete. 
When using another QC compatible charger, it doesn't charges as quick but it is consistent right till 100%. Considering that, it seems both charges the phone in total equal time.

Only Huawei branded chargers will work. Just received this one. Works perfectly.Original 9V 2A EU US Adaptive Fast Wall Charger for Huawei P9 Plus HTC Oneplus | eBay
And it works in very interesting way. Yet I think it really saves a battery. I have a power meter in my 220V power outlet. At first charger kicks at 16W power mode. Later another mode I've noticed was some kind of trickle charging, when power meter showed the charger changing it's power used: 16W - 11.5W - 16W - 11.5W. Just more later - steady 11.5W. And it has to do a lot not with how much battery left, but with it's temperature. If your phone just feels warm in your hand - the charger won't kick to 16W mode even at the beginning.
The final result here: started charging at 34%. 30 minutes later I had 74%. With 3000mAh battery inside 40 percent in 30 minutes seems to be quite impressive to me.
PS. Phone also indicated charger properly, so you will see on-screen message it is not "Charging", but "Fast Charging".

title: Can't Sync Google contacts, what can i do?﻿ Device: Huawei P9 Plus 128gb Vie-AL10

thread.text: I just bought a Huawei P9 Plus 128gb model VIE-AL10, from China. Im having trouble getting it to sync my google contacts. So far i have downloaded google contacts sync but it just isn't working, what can i do?﻿

I got it working, someone in the XDA Forums managed to do it, so here is the solution:
Lets start from scratch to make it simpler.
Remove Google Contacts via the apps section of the phone
Download Google Contact Sync APK and install it (Even if you already have it) get this one: https://www.apkmirror.com/apk/google...-apk-download/
Reboot phone
Go into permission manager and select Google Contacts Sync and make sure it is set as "Trust this app"
Then go into Apps via Settings and search for Google Contacts Sync and select permissions, make sure "Contacts" is enabled as per screenshot http://anonpix.com/images/2016/05/16/7qEOb.png
Reboot phone
Check your accounts and you should see Google Contact Sync

title: Huawei P9 , Power consumption?

thread.text:
My Huawei P9 phone is now 3 days old and i´m wondering why battery drains so fast, even in stanby. I charged phone full 100% an after few hours there is 70 - 80% power left.(idle) I have a"clever" battery profile in use an there is no any "lot of power" using apps running.
Is this normal stituation or am i middle of troubles?
Thank You

For the first few charge cycles (100% to when the phone shuts off), the drain may seem a bit high. Also some apps may be updating in the background, which will increase the battery drain. And check the Battery in "Settings" - tap the graph to get to the next page and look at the mobile signal line at the bottom. If it's anything but solid green or white, the phone's transmitter is running at higher power because the signal is weak, and that uses more battery too.

Welcome to Android Central! Seeing some battery stats may be helpful. Charge up to 100%, then let it drain to 20-30% with normal usage, without charging in between. Then show us:
1. The main Settings>Battery screen.
2. The fullscreen battery graph screen (which shows Awake time and Cell Signal Strength).
3. The Screen category (to see total Screen On time).
4. The Cell Standby category, if present (to see Time Without Signal).http://forums.androidcentral.com/amb...d-central.html
Thank you for your help, i.ll think problem is solved now. Factory reset performed and maybe themes causes abnormal power leak.
I had the same issue and turning off the backup made a huge difference

thread.text:
Everytime I think I've found the perfect phone for me, when I look deeper at the specs there are some compromises. To be expected but some of these are strange.
- NFC on single-sim but not on dual-sim versions (can't figure out how they are connected, Samsung and Xiaomi can manage both together)
- Dual-sim: 32GB/3GB version supports less network bands than the 64GB/4GB version (why?)
- Dual-sim 64GB/4GB version on comes in a single colour, Haze Gold! (never been a fan of gold phones)
Also, a couple of questions I hope someone can help with regarding dual-sim:
1. 4G+3G or 4G+2G?
2. What does dual-standby mean compared to dual-active? (from what I've read dual-active means 2 radios so both sims can receive/make calls at the same time but uses more battery life. Dual-standby means can only receive/make calls from 1 sim at a time which is fine with me but what is confusing is can you receive calls and sms on one sim whilst using data on the other sim at the same time?)
Thanks
The dual sim is probably the second guess. Duals usually are.

Just to let you guys know.
The Huawei P9 supports Band 12 on T-Mobile and Band 17 on AT&T, alongside B2 and B4 on both.Note that only the single-sim variant alongside the 64GB dual-SIM variant supports the above bands. The 32GB dual-SIM variant doesn't.
And while the phone does support some LTE bands used by Sprint, US Cellular and Verizon, it apparently does not work on their CDMA network, so if you're on either of those carriers, this phone is a pass unless Huawei makes a version that works on both GSM and CDMA networks for its upcoming official Stateside launch.http://forums.androidcentral.com/hua...7-support.html

title: If you're wondering whether the Huawei P9 has B12/17 support...

thread.text:
...This was on Unbox Therapy.
According to the spec sheet, Band 12 (T-Mobile) and Band 17 (AT&T) seem to be fully-supported on the P9.
This may vary between different variants of the same phone, however.
If you're thinking of importing the device (it's going to cost a pretty penny, however), the P9 might be a safe bet.

Get hype, great news, I know what my next phone will be
Posted via the one and only Honor 5x

Yeah, definitely variant dependent. Got this from the Huawei website:
Dual-sim 4GB version seems to support the most bands but also no NFC and only a single colour.

replies.text:
Thanks for the extra bit of information.
Yeah, it looks like you'll need to get either the single-SIM or the 64GB dual-SIM version just to ensure that LTE bands on many major US carriers are supported by the phone.
Another thing I noticed is "3G-TD-SCDMA". Does this actually support CDMA?
UPDATE: Checked FreqCheck and it apparently doesn't work on Sprint and Verizon's CDMA network. So if you're on either of those carriers, this phone is a pass.

title: Huawei announces the new P9

thread.text: Looks like it might have a really good camera. From the blog: Huawei announces the P9 and P9 Plus with dual Leica cameras | Android Central

Have been looking forward to this announcement!
P9 looks promising (not interested in the P9 Plus). Here are my positives so far:
- Quite compact (a little taller than I would have liked but only a couple of millmeters more than the S7 and Mi 5)
- 5.2" 1080p and 3000mAh battery is good.
- No glossy plastic or shiny grubby glass on the back (Yes!!!), and plenty of colour choices.
- Dual SIM version
- 3GB/32GB or 4GB/64GB version
- Dual-camera sounds interesting
- Support for 18 LTE bands!
- Optimised file system (so hopefully no lag over time, wonder if this is similar to UFS 2.0?)
IR Blaster but not sure if it is only on the Plus version?
May be my next phone. Just need to know the price...
It does look like to be an interesting phone.

I looked at a site promising to reveal the price, but it did not😠. So I'll guess at £400 for the P9 in the UK.
Posted via the Android Central App

title: Hands on with the P9

thread.text:
The blog published a hands on article with the P9: Huawei P9 + P9 Plus hands-on: Dual cameras in Huawei's new high-end duo | Android Central
Both look to be like a couple of pretty good devices.
I'm excited to see a good photo comparison to see if those dual cameras really make that much of a difference.

Very interesting devices for photography buffs. They've used the Summarit name, I see. The original Summarit was a 7-element 50mm f1.5 first produced in the 1930's, but there have been other Leica lenses bearing the name since then.
Posted via the Android Central App
